You don't fund money to the poor directly. You use it to establish programs like the G.E.D program that helps dropouts get some sort of credibility etc.
Thank you for giving a proper answer. Not that I agree. I think you have a lot of your views mixed up, you don't seem to really understand what you're talking about half of the time.
Frell:

Theres instances where perception is pretty bad and you can dismiss it quickly, usually without enough explanation that it leaves gaps :P. That goes for the western view of Europe and vice versa.

Europe is the western world you tool. America was considered to ‘join’ for lack of a better world, later.

Those American values your country was founded on, I think you need to take a closer look at those. They weren’t afaik conservative.

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Mopman:

(perhaps not healthcare, but would your thoughts on that perhaps be different if you country wasnt in the middle of a massive scandal?)

They wouldn’t change. Alot of our democrats are actually against the bill for very serious reasons, one of the major ones is the slower medicinal advances for the entire world due to the lack of private profit for R&D funding, which probably isnt much of a joke because of how common cancer is becoming. And then the shortage of doctors wouldn’t be very convenient. There are alot of reasons behind it really. But you’ll have to realize what its like for a country like the US to be forced under a policy like this.

Mopman:

you also seem to be in denial

Theres instances where perception is pretty bad and you can dismiss it quickly, usually without enough explanation that it leaves gaps :P. That goes for the western view of Europe and vice versa.

Mopman:

but you’re clearly big into the idea of capitalism, i don’t think i have to expand there. but you’ve also in other posts expressed that you think the state has a responsibility to take control of basic humanitarian issues such as education and welfare, where the private sector fails (perhaps not healthcare, but would your thoughts on that perhaps be different if you country wasnt in the middle of a massive scandal?)

Well yea, i mean you gotta help people. But finding a solution is very hard to do without doing something history has proved faulty.

Read full topic

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

well, again, black and white doesn’t work that well, and its better to think of these things as a scale

but you’re clearly big into the idea of capitalism, i don’t think i have to expand there. but you’ve also in other posts expressed that you think the state has a responsibility to take control of basic humanitarian issues such as education and welfare, where the private sector fails (perhaps not healthcare, but would your thoughts on that perhaps be different if you country wasnt in the middle of a massive scandal?)

thats textbook (social) liberalism, surely? from where im standing, we’re both very similar in political beliefs, except perhaps you are a bit closer to conservatism than me (“more center” or perhaps slightly right of center i guess, im not sure on where people generally put the boundaries, its not like i took politics at college or anything) and you also seem to be in denial

or perhaps i’m wrong, after all i only know you through this forum. but thats how it looks from here.

edit: regarding the view being mashed because of different countries, sure, you’re totally right and theres nothing wrong or unusual about that. it’s why i keep prefixing “liberalism” with “social” - if i said liberalism here, everyone would assume i was talking about social liberalism anyway because the biggest party that self-identifies as “liberal” here is the lib dems, and they are pretty big on the social liberalism. whereas in the USA, you guys probably think of something closer to traditional liberalism (also the word liberal seems to be derogatory in the usa for some reason, which is mighty fucking strange when the people using it in that way are usually the same people who claim that america was founded on freedom, liberty and free trade, which are cornerstones of social liberalism at least to many people)

none of this changes the policies and the beliefs, though, which is what i meant with my little tongue in cheek “in denial”. if you believe in liberalism, you are surely at least somewhere in the “liberal” box, whether you like the term or not

Read full topic

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Mopman:

Thanks for confirming you don’t know what socialism is, so that I don’t have to just guess.

then learn me

so·cial·ism
noun \ˈsō-shə-ˌli-zəm
Definition of SOCIALISM
1
: any of various economic and political theories advocating collective or governmental ownership and administration of the means of production and distribution of goods
2
a : a system of society or group living in which there is no private property

social security and national healthcare fall in there pretty nicely, dont they?

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:55, topic:367156”][quote author=Frell link=topic=463342.msg3395085#msg3395085 date=1289272661]
Im not against the ideas behind socialism (helping everyone), but it just wont work anywhere. There is always something wrong with any country using it.[/quote]

My problem isn’t that you have backed-up arguments about socialism, my problem is that you consider countries (and policies) to be socialist that aren’t even remotely close, which just makes me think you have no idea what socialism is.[/quote]
National healthcare - (pure)socialist, social security - socialist, and any entitlement programs are close enough to socialism that we’ve felt the effects, even at such a minor scale.

Mopman:

This isn’t something just you do, it’s something that’s big in conservative America, and I have no idea why. McCarthy’s memory, maybe. Rofl.

Conservatives try to conserve the American values the founding fathers put in place. The country was built to try to avoid any such thing.

Read full topic

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Frell:

Im not against the ideas behind socialism (helping everyone), but it just wont work anywhere. There is always something wrong with any country using it.

My problem isn’t that you have backed-up arguments about socialism, my problem is that you consider countries (and policies) to be socialist that aren’t even remotely close, which just makes me think you have no idea what socialism is.

EDIT: As the website you linked says, arguing nomenclature is pointless (which is why I’ve always stayed away from it before) - except in this case, it’s not pointless, because its more than just nomenclature - you are letting socialism and reality merge in your mind and using it as a big strawman, resulting in a big mish-mash argument that is partly against actual policies, partly fucking i-don’t-know-what pie in the sky arguments against actual socialism that is completely irrelevant.

This isn’t something just you do, it’s something that’s big in conservative America, and I have no idea why. McCarthy’s memory, maybe. Rofl.

Read full topic

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Those rich people don’t need all that money. They don’t pay their fair share of taxes. And a lot of good can be done if all that money is taken away from those people, who don’t need it anyway, and is given to other less fortunate people so that they can have better opportunities to advance their lives.

See anything wrong with that? Like people knowing that the more money they make the more money their government will take? All it does is destroy incentive until no one wants to work (more than the next guy) and the country goes bankrupt. inb4 Sweden, because it doesn’t work there either. Its just a doomed system thats fall has been prolonged by its income. Even Volvo is only able to survive this harsh system by outsourcing outside of Sweden, and i dont doubt the majority of companies use this tactic.

Im not against the ideas behind socialism (helping everyone), but it just wont work anywhere. There is always something wrong with any country using it. Our problem with our socialist policies is fraud and federal funding. We need strict guidelines to make sure only the people who actually need them get the help, and the rest get it but are forced off of it gradually. Our capitalistic economy allows some of our socialist policies to make it by because of the mass income we get from private internal businesses allowed by capitalism. And they barely make it by.

http://socialismdoesntwork.com/why-socialism-doesnt-work explains why wealth redistribution eventually crumbles also

Read full topic

Frell:

You don’t fund money to the poor directly. You use it to establish programs like the G.E.D program that helps dropouts get some sort of credibility etc.

Welcome to Social Liberalism, a concept well established in Europe that cries itself to sleep when you call it Socialism.

item.title: US owes China
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Greeny:

Replying with a mindless cliche is a beatifully American response. I adore irony.

You don’t fund money to the poor directly. You use it to establish programs like the G.E.D program that helps dropouts get some sort of credibility etc.

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:46, topic:367156”][quote author=Frell link=topic=463342.msg3393504#msg3393504 date=1289145983]
Uhhh, i think you’re thinking of social security & unemployment. Here, welfare is a different program that IIRC pays any family whose income falls below a certain amount. They’re provided with payed section 8 housing, food stamps, medicaid etc.
[/quote]

My bad.

We have a welfare program too. It’s called ‘Bijstand’. Basically, if your income falls below a certain level, you receive benefits ranging from plain money to compensation for certain mandatory expenses.

It’s almost impossible to receive welfare when you’re working. Most receivers receive it because they are unable to work, and don’t receive other benefits. It’s no fun receiving it. You only receive the amount you need to reach the maximum. Let’s say that someone living alone needs €1500 to stay alive, and he earns €1000 he only receives €500.

Besides, if you have more then a certain amount of money, either on your bank account or from the value of your house, you have to use that to stay alive first.

Just because the US doesn’t know how to make proper laws that’s abuse-free doesn’t mean that a bit of Socialism is something diabolical. It means that you have no idea what you are doing.[/quote]
I support socialist policies as long as they dont cause us to go bankrupt and they’re not ran federally. Our welfare is capable of paying for someones life completely, thats why we need more to urge them to work for themselves.

Read full topic
